title: Energy - Hollow Cone and Solid Disk

content.description:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A hollow cone and uniform solid disk, both of radius <math alttext="uppercase R equals, 0.30 meters" overflow="scroll"> <mi>R</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0.30</mn> <mspace width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi> </math>, have the same rotational inertia <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math>. The cone and disk are initially at rest and suspended on axles that pass through an axis perpendicular to their circular faces.

In Scenario <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, strings are wrapped around the outside of the cone and disk and attached to motors, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The string wrapped around the outside of the cone is wrapped from the base of the cone to its tip, such that the radial distance <math alttext="lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> between the axis of the cone and the point at which the string is no longer in contact with the cone is given by <math alttext="lowercase r of theta equals, uppercase R minus, the fraction with numerator theta and denominator B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>θ</mi><mi>B</mi></mfrac></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> is the angular displacement of the cone measured in radians and <math alttext="B equals, 20 pi radians per meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn><mi>π</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/m</mtext></mstyle></math>.

At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the motors exert a constant force of magnitude <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> on each string, causing the cone and disk to rotate. The strings do not slip on the surfaces of either object. At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the cone and disk are rotating, but each has rotated less than three revolutions.
content.question:
(a) At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the instantaneous powers being delivered to the cone and disk by the motors are <math alttext="P sub C" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="P sub D" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></msub></math>, respectively. Indicate if <math alttext="P sub C" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></msub></math> is greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="P sub D" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></msub></math>.

The angular speed of the cone when the cone has completed three revolutions is <math alttext="omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.
(b) Derive an expression for <math alttext="omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> in terms of <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math>, <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

In Scenario <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the cone is reversed such that the string is wrapped around its outside from the tip of the cone to its base, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. In this new scenario, the motor again exerts a constant force of magnitude <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> on the string. In this scenario, the angular speed of the cone when the cone has completed three revolutions is <math alttext="omega sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

(c) Indicate if <math alttext="omega sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="omega sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
